channel.title: BBC News - Technology

item.title: WhatsApp issued second-largest GDPR fine of €225m
item.description: The Irish data watchdog has handed WhatsApp the second-highest ever GDPR fine.

item.title: Sir Salman Rushdie to serialise book via email newsletter
item.description: The Booker Prize-winning author will serialise a new novella on the Substack newsletter publishing platform.

item.title: Apple to allow Netflix-type apps a sign-up link
item.description: Apps offering books, videos or music will be able to offer a website link to sign up and manage accounts.

item.title: US states to accept driver's licence on iPhones
item.description: Apple's new ID system for its Wallet will be rolled out at airports to start.

item.title: Afghanistan: Facebook says it helped people flee, including staff
item.description: The flight arrived in Mexico City on Wednesday, with 175 Afghan citizens on board, including 75 children.

item.title: Twitter tests safety mode feature to silence abuse
item.description: Once enabled in settings, the new feature will automatically sniff out abusive tweets.

item.title: Investigation into hacked "map" of UK gun owners
item.description: Animal rights activists have published a "map" of thousands of gun owners and their addresses.

item.title: Children's internet code: What is it and how will it work?
item.description: The ICO's Children's Code will make technology companies reassess how they offer services to children.

item.title: Fake Banksy NFT sold through artist's website for £244k
item.description: Duped buyer says he feels "burned" after apparent hack of Banksy website.

item.title: Coinbase users fear hacking after erroneous emails
item.description: Some users panicked after 125,000 emails were sent mistakenly warning of changed security settings.

item.title: YouTube signs Twitch video-game streamer Dr Lupo
item.description: Twitch says it wishes the American, 34, "nothing but the best in everything that comes next".

item.title: Tokyo 2020: Toyota restarts driverless vehicles after accident
item.description: A visually impaired athlete from Japan's judo team was hit by one of the e-Palette pods on Thursday.

item.title: Breast cancer: The AI tool trained to spot the disease
item.description: Artificial intelligence trained to spot the disease is tested at Nottingham University Hospital.

item.title: Little penguin feeding behaviour revealed with trackers
item.description: Ten males were fitted with sensors in the breeding season to give greater insight into the birds.

item.title: Gadget reviews: Smart cool boxes and neck fans
item.description: Lara Lewington looks at some of the latest gadgets to help make the most of your summer.

item.title: Ryan Reynolds: Video games and the making of Free Guy
item.description: Actor and producer Ryan Reynolds on preparing to play a character caught up in a multiplayer game.

item.title: The NI inventor who saved thousands of lives
item.description: The plane ejector seat was invented by James Martin, from Crossgar in County Down, in 1944.

item.title: Can apps move the #MeToo movement forward?
item.description: Reporting sexual harassment at work is getting easier thanks to new technologies.

item.title: Why is there a chip shortage?
item.description: The big chip crunch is really biting now, leaving even the most unexpected industries in crisis.

item.title: Why phone scams are so difficult to tackle
item.description: Phone fraud, both via calls and text messages, has soared during the pandemic.

item.title: How virtual reality can help to recruit and train staff
item.description: VR headsets are making a leap from fun gimmick to serious tool for firms' workforce management.

item.title: Just how hard is it to recycle a jumbo jet?
item.description: Thousands of aircraft were left on the tarmac due to Covid, and many will now be broken up for parts.

item.title: Would you let a robot lawyer defend you?
item.description: Why artificial intelligence is increasingly being used by the legal profession.

item.title: How can new technology protect outdoor workers?
item.description: Working outdoors in extreme heat can be deadly, new tech and better protection for workers could help.

item.title: Sharing apps are booming but will the kindness continue?
item.description: The pandemic sparked a surge in activity for sharing apps like Olio but has the trend run its course?
